task.title: 3. Using content references
task.shortdesc: Use content references to manage lists of terms and definitions.

section.title: Introduction to content references
section.p: I think content references ("conrefs") are DITA's killer feature. This is very powerful and is probably a "killer feature".

section.title: Are lists of terms and definitions actually needed?
section.p: Don't add abbreviations to these lists.

section.title: What to conref
section.p: You can conref whole section elements. This probably isn't te canonical way of using conrefs, because the computer documentation tradition seems to require much more of the alteration of sentence and meaning rather than pulling whole paragraphs across.
For standards, this mechanism allows simple and predictable transclusion for smallish packets of text, with might or might not have titles.

6 DITA content references â€“ tutorial: how to manage a centralised glossary I'll demonstrate how conrefs can be helpful in producing policy and procedure documents. These kind of documents can typically have a life of three years.

This is short enough that they might not warrant publishing professionally, but long enough that they will be referred to by other documents, and eventually be cannibalised by successor documents. One typical casuality of this arrangement is the lack of a consistent list of organisational terms and definitions.

It's just hard to keep everything current with this kind of churn. Conrefs can help manage these. Rather than copy or write terms and definitions in a document, they could be held in a DITA glossary topic reserved for this purpose, called "glossary_bank.dita". It could be hundreds of entries long.

Global glossary: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE glossgroup PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Glossary Group//EN" "glossgroup.dtd"> <glossgroup id="gemstone_glossary"> <title>Bank of gemstone terms and definitions</title> <glossentry id="diamond"> <glossterm>diamond</glossterm> <glossdef>gemstone, clear and colourless with renowned physical properties, that is a metastable allotrope of carbon</glossdef> </glossentry> <glossentry id="emerald"> <glossterm>emerald</glossterm> <glossdef>gemstone, coloured green by trace amounts of chromium and sometimes vanadium, that is a variety of the mineral beryl</glossdef> </glossentry> <glossentry id="ruby"> <glossterm>ruby</glossterm> <glossdef>gemstone, coloured pink to blood-red, that is a variety of the mineral corundum (aluminium oxide)</glossdef> </glossentry> <glossentry id="sapphire"> <glossterm>sapphire</glossterm> <glossdef>gemstone, coloured blue, yellow, pink, purple, orange, or greenish by trace amounts of elements such as iron, titanium, chromium, copper, or magnesium, that is a variety of the mineral corundum (aluminium oxide)</glossdef> </glossentry> </glossgroup>

This is our global list for use throughout the organisation. A map for a document would include this bank as a resource-only topic. Our map could then contain another glossary. This second glossary pulls the required terms over from the global bank.

The main advantage here is that the glossary bank can be shared with all documents. Corrections made to the glossary bank will feed through to all documents. When writing a document, you can just pick the term you want from the bank and you will be confident that it's correct and up to date. I'm using another glossary topic (rather than pull the terms directly into a, say, task topic) because glossentry elements belong to the glossgroup topic specialisation. Our glossary, using a conref to pull the emerald and the ruby terms from the glossary bank: Glossary for this cut gemstones specification Map, containing the following: the glossary bank, marked as "resource-only" (so we don't render it) our manual's glossary, which pulls over two terms ("emerald" and "ruby") using conrefs the emerald and ruby topics a relationship table, which will allow the reader to jump between the two topics. Glossary tutorial The "requirements_for_emeralds.dita" topic looks like this. (The ruby topic is its equivalent.) I added a cross-reference. DITA practitioners generally don't like cross-references, preferring to use relationship tables exclusively (which link topics together and where the links are usually rendered at the end of their topics). I usually agree with this, but topics containing long lists might be better served by links to the item rather than the whole topic. Psychic editing using DITA's conref push
Normal conref allows you to pull text in from a resource. Conref push works in reverse, and allows you to push your new text into existing content without modifying that content!
You can modify text without going anywhere near it! It's like telekinesis. There are untold uses for this magic.

Map: Doctor Who test Here's the original text. Note that you do need id numbers to give the conref push feature something to look for: List of First Doctor serials
The Web Planet

This is a peculiar story. There are no humanoid monsters. The Zarbi runs into the camera.

 The text renders to this: List of First Doctor serials The Web Planet This is a peculiar story. There are no humanoid monsters. The Zarbi runs into the camera. Okay. I'm going to modify this beautiful passage wih conref push.
